message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: MIPLIB 2017: data-driven compilation of the 6thÂ mixed-integer programming library
Paper Abstract: Abstract We report on the selection process leading to the sixth version of the Mixed Integer Programming Library, MIPLIB 2017. Selected from an initial pool of 5721 instances, the new MIPLIB 2017 collection consists of 1065 instances. A subset of 240 instances was specially selected for benchmarking solver performance. For the first time, these sets were compiled using a data-driven selection process supported by the solution of a sequence of mixed integer optimization problems, which encode requirements on diversity and balancedness with respect to instance features and performance data.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've performed a web search for "Mathematical optimization" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Mathematical optimization (alternatively spelled optimisation) or mathematical programming is the selection of a best element, with regard to some criteria, from some set of available alternatives. More specifically, mathematical optimization is the theory and computation of extrema or stationary points of functions.

## Main Subfields

It is generally divided into two subfields: discrete optimization and continuous optimization.

## Key Concepts

Several important areas within mathematical optimization include:

- **Constrained Optimization**: In mathematical optimization, constrained optimization (in some contexts called constraint optimization) is the process of optimizing an objective function with respect to some variables in the presence of constraints on those variables.

- **Combinatorial Optimization**: Combinatorial optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that consists of finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects, where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a discrete set.

- **Dynamic Programming**: Dynamic programming is the approach to solve the stochastic optimization problem with stochastic, randomness, and unknown model parameters. It studies the case in which the optimization strategy is based on splitting the problem into smaller subproblems.

## Historical Background

The term "linear programming" for certain optimization cases was due to George B. Dantzig, although much of the theory had been introduced by Leonid Kantorovich in 1939.

Here are the search results for "Algorithm":

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, an algorithm is a finite sequence of mathematically rigorous instructions, typically used to solve a class of specific problems or to perform a computation.(no content)Algorithms are used as specifications for performing calculations and data processing.

## Key Characteristics

Starting from an initial state and initial input (perhaps empty), the instructions describe a computation that, when executed, proceeds through a finite number of well-defined successive states, eventually producing "output" and terminating at a final ending state.(no content)The transition from one state to the next is not necessarily deterministic; some algorithms, known as randomized algorithms, incorporate random input.

## Implementation

Most algorithms are intended to be implemented as computer programs. However, algorithms are also implemented by other means, such as in a biological neural network (for example, the human brain performing arithmetic or an insect looking for food), in an electrical circuit, or a mechanical device.

## Historical Background

The earliest evidence of algorithms is found in ancient Mesopotamian mathematics. A Sumerian clay tablet found in Shuruppak near Baghdad and dated to c. 2500 BC describes the earliest division algorithm.

The search results also include information about specific types of algorithms like A* pathfinding, Dijkstra's algorithm, greedy algorithms, and many others that are used in various fields of computer science and mathematics.

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"Talk:Mixed integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Mixed_integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Quadratic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_programming"},{"title":"FortMP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FortMP"},{"title":"MINTO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MINTO"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"},{"title":"MPS (format) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MPS_(format)"},{"title":"Sparse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparse"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Mixed Integer Programming:

## Definition

Mixed Integer (Linear) Programming (MIP or MILP) is a problem where only some of the unknown variables are required to be integers, while the rest can be continuous (real-valued). These problems are generally NP-hard because they are even more general than ILP (Integer Linear Programming) programs.

## Applications

Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling. Other practical applications include:

- Agricultural production planning, which involves determining production yield for several crops that can share resources (such as land, labor, capital, seeds, fertilizer), with the objective to maximize total production without exceeding available resources
- Service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks, such as assigning buses or subways to individual routes to meet a timetable and equip them with drivers

## Solution Methods

Mixed integer programming problems are solved using branch and bound algorithm. MINTO is a software system that solves mixed integer programming problems by a branch and bound algorithm with linear programming relaxations.

Additionally, Google OR-Tools is a free and open-source software suite developed by Google for solving linear programming (LP), mixed integer programming (MIP), constraint programming (CP), vehicle routing (VRP), and related optimization problems.

Here are the search results for "Benchmarking":

## Overview

Benchmarking is the practice of comparing business processes and performance metrics to industry bests and best practices from other companies.(no content)Dimensions typically measured are quality, time and cost.

## Purpose and Application

Benchmarking is used to measure performance using a specific indicator (cost per unit of measure, productivity per unit of measure, cycle time of x per unit of measure or defects per unit of measure) resulting in a metric of performance that is then compared to others.(no content)This allows organizations to develop plans on how to make improvements or adapt specific best practices, usually with the aim of increasing some aspect of performance.

## Continuous Process

Benchmarking may be a one-off event, but is often treated as a continuous process in which organizations continually seek to improve their practices.

## Computing Context

In the technology field, a benchmark is the result of running a computer program, or a set of programs, in order to assess the relative performance of an object, by running a number of standard tests and trials against it.

## Specialized Forms

Benchmarking has various specialized applications:
- Cost benchmarking is the measurement, refinement and analysis of one's Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) when compared to market peers.
- In statistics, benchmarking is a method of using auxiliary information to adjust the sampling weights used in an estimation process, in order to yield more accurate estimates of totals.

Here are the search results for "Benchmarking":

## Overview

Benchmarking is the practice of comparing business processes and performance metrics to industry bests and best practices from other companies.(no content)Dimensions typically measured are quality, time and cost.

## Purpose and Application

Benchmarking is used to measure performance using a specific indicator (cost per unit of measure, productivity per unit of measure, cycle time of x per unit of measure or defects per unit of measure) resulting in a metric of performance that is then compared to others.(no content)This allows organizations to develop plans on how to make improvements or adapt specific best practices, usually with the aim of increasing some aspect of performance.

## Continuous Process

Benchmarking may be a one-off event, but is often treated as a continuous process in which organizations continually seek to improve their practices.

## Computing Context

In the technology field, a benchmark is the result of running a computer program, or a set of programs, in order to assess the relative performance of an object, by running a number of standard tests and trials against it.

## Specialized Forms

Benchmarking has various specialized applications:
- Cost benchmarking is the measurement, refinement and analysis of one's Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) when compared to market peers.
- In statistics, benchmarking is a method of using auxiliary information to adjust the sampling weights used in an estimation process, in order to yield more accurate estimates of totals.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about instance selection in machine learning:

## Definition and Purpose

Instance selection (or dataset reduction, or dataset condensation) is an important data pre-processing step that can be applied in many machine learning (or data mining) tasks.(no content)Approaches for instance selection can be applied for reducing the original dataset to a manageable volume, leading to a reduction of the computational resources that are necessary for performing the learning process.

## Benefits

Beyond computational efficiency, instance selection offers quality improvements. Algorithms of instance selection can also be applied for removing noisy instances, before applying learning algorithms, which can improve the accuracy in classification problems.

## Categories of Algorithms

Instance selection algorithms can be grouped in two main classes, according to what instances they select: algorithms that preserve the instances at the boundaries of classes and algorithms that preserve the internal instances of the classes.(no content)Within the category of algorithms that select instances at the boundaries it is possible to cite DROP3, ICF and LSBo. On the other hand, within the category of algorithms that select internal instances, it is possible to mention ENN and LSSm.(no content)The algorithms LDIS, CDIS and XLDIS select the densest instances in a given arbitrary neighborhood, and the selected instances can include both, border and internal instances.

Links: [{"title":"Solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solver"},{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"Maze-solving algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maze-solving_algorithm"},{"title":"Sudoku solving algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sudoku_algorithms"},{"title":"Simplex algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simplex_algorithm"},{"title":"Iterative method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterative_method"},{"title":"List of algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_algorithms"},{"title":"SIMPLE algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SIMPLE_algorithm"},{"title":"Optimal solutions for the Rubik's Cube - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_solutions_for_the_Rubik's_Cube"},{"title":"HHL algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HHL_algorithm"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of solver algorithms:

## General Definition

A solver is a piece of mathematical software that 'solves' a mathematical problem by taking problem descriptions in some sort of generic form and calculating their solution.

## Types of Problems and Solvers

Types of problems with existing dedicated solvers include: linear and non-linear equations, systems of linear equations, nonlinear systems, and systems of polynomial equations.

## Key Solver Approaches

Several major solver algorithms and approaches exist:

1. **General Problem Solver (GPS)**: The General Problem Solver is a particular computer program created in 1957 by Herbert Simon, J. C. Shaw, and Allen Newell intended to work as a universal problem solver. It was the first computer program that separated its knowledge of problems (in the form of domain rules) from its strategy of how to solve problems.

2. **SAT Solvers**: A SAT solver is a computer program which aims to solve the Boolean satisfiability problem. It outputs whether a formula is satisfiable or unsatisfiable.

3. **Linear Programming (Simplex)**: In mathematical optimization, Dantzig's simplex algorithm (or simplex method) is an algorithm for linear programming.

4. **Iterative Methods**: An iterative method is a mathematical procedure that uses an initial value to generate a sequence of improving approximate solutions for a class of problems.

The specific solver used depends on the problem type and the desired optimization criteria.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors, edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

todos.content: Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
If validation errors: Fix the errors, edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: No errors, validation passed on second run

message_text:
## Summary

I have successfully completed the paper analysis and triple extraction for the MIPLIB 2017 paper. Here's what was accomplished:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: **Contribution** (the paper proposes MIPLIB 2017, a new dataset and data-driven selection process)

### Extracted Triples (5 total)

1. **Integer programming** (concept, uses)
   - Mixed integer programming is the core optimization problem formulation for MIPLIB 2017 instances

2. **Mathematical optimization** (concept, uses)
   - The paper uses mixed integer optimization to encode selection requirements in the data-driven process

3. **Benchmarking** (task, proposes)
   - The paper creates a benchmarking subset of 240 instances for measuring solver performance

4. **Solver** (tool, uses)
   - The paper evaluates MIP solver performance and uses performance data in the selection process

5. **Instance selection** (method, proposes)
   - The paper introduces a novel data-driven instance selection process to compile MIPLIB 2017

### Validation
â **All validation checks passed** - The triples_output.json file has been validated successfully with 5 properly formatted triples covering 2 concepts, 1 task, 1 tool, and 1 method.

Sources:
- [Integer programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming)
- [Mathematical optimization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization)
- [Benchmarking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benchmarking)
- [Solver](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solver)
- [Instance selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instance_selection)
